entry.title: Migrating Point-to-Point Asynchronous Scenarios Using the Migration Tool in SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
This blog post is part of the series Master Blog: SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite Migration – Tool and Guidance exploring how to migrate various integration patterns from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite using the Migration Tool. In this blog, we will focus on the Point-to-Point (P2P) Asynchronous pattern, which is one of the most common and fundamental integration scenarios.

 

Objective

The goal of this blog is to explain how the Migration Tool supports P2P asynchronous integrations, including:

  • Key configuration options and technical considerations
  • Best practices to ensure reliable and decoupled communication
  • How to implement JMS decoupling and Idempotent Processing effectively

 

Understanding the Point-to-Point Asynchronous Pattern

In a Point-to-Point (P2P) asynchronous integration, a message is sent from a sender to a receiver without a response message. This pattern promotes decoupling between systems, improves reliability, and allows retry mechanisms to ensure delivery in case you are using JMS queues. By default, the Migration Tool will enable JMS queues during migration.

If there are constraints on the limit of available JMS queues, the tool also supports direct communication without JMS, though this reduces decoupling and resilience. If you are migrating a high number of asynchronous interfaces, SAP recommends using the pipeline approach, which will not be covered in this blog. You can find more information in Pipeline Concept and  Migration Tooling now supporting migration via the pipeline approach.

 

Migration Tool Support for P2P Asynchronous Scenarios using Standard Approach

The Migration Tool automates most of the effort by generating a ready-to-use Integration Flow (iFlow) and the corresponding configuration objects in SAP Cloud Integration.

Depending on your settings, the tool can generate Integration Flows that:

1. Decouple with JMS Queue: Use JMS queues for decoupling between sender and receiver systems (only shown for Asynchronous interfaces):

When you select this option, the Migration Tool creates two Integration Processes within the generated iFlow:

  • Inbound Process
    • Receives the message from the migrated Sender Component and Communication Channel
    • Forwards the message to the JMS queue
  • Outbound Process
    • Reads the message from the JMS queue
    • Performs any required processing (e.g., message mapping, data transformation)

Delivers the message to the receiver system

Please note that you need to maintain the name of the JMS queue post-migration using the already created external parameters:

2. Idempotent Process at the Receiver Side: Use the idempotent process call if you want to make sure that the message will be delivered exactly once to the target system:

When you select this option, the generated iFlow will include an Idempotent Process Call. This mechanism ensures that a message is delivered exactly once to the receiver system, avoiding duplicate postings.

The API call at the receiver system is wrapped then into this local integration process.

There are receiver adapters that do supports idempotency such as SOAP RM, XI and IDoc. In these cases, it’s preferable that you don’t use the Idempotent option on Migration Tool and choose to handle it directly in the adapter. You can find more information in Special Use Cases: SAP RM vs XI vs IDoc.

 

Post-Migration Activities and Special Scenarios

While the Migration Tool significantly accelerates the transition from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite, a few manual fine-tuning steps are typically required.

Generic Post-Migration Steps

After migrating a P2P Asynchronous interface:

  1. Review and update external parameters for sender and receiver connectivity.
  2. Define the JMS queue name to be used in both Integration Processes (in case checkbox is marked during wizard). This can be done in the external parameters’ configuration view.
  3. Update
  4. Review if you want to change the value of the header SAP_Sender according to the naming convention that will be adopted on SAP Integration Suite.

Manual Activities Depending on Integration Scenario

You can also find below few examples of manual activities post-migration that needs to be performed depending on the content of your integration scenario:

  1. Functions like RFC Lookup or JDBC Lookup on Graphical Message Mapping are not automatically converted. Replace them with equivalent Integration Suite adapters or externalized APIs. Tutorials are available for JDBC lookups and RFC lookups.
  2. If your interface is using any custom code (e.g., UDF, Function Library, Java Mapping) or XSLT that have additional dependencies, Therefore, you need to export them from SAP Process Orchestration and import into your Integration Flow
  3. If your interface is using a fault message handling, this won’t be migrated using the Migration Tool. Therefore, you need to import the mapping using the standalone functionality and add an exception handling subprocess into the migrated iFlow

Please refer to the Known Limitations of Migration Tooling for additional insights into cases that may require manual adjustments after migration. we will explore specific topics in more depth, such as XSLT transformation differences between SAP Process Orchestration and SAP Integration Suite, custom code migration, fault message handling, and other advanced migration scenarios.

 

Async-Sync Bridge Support

The Point-to-Point Asynchronous pattern also covers scenarios using an Async-Sync bridge.

In SAP Process Orchestration, an asynchronous interface is converted into synchronous using the RequestResponseBean module, enabling a response message to be sent back to the sender asynchronously using a second interface object.

The Migration Tool can migrate this Async-Sync bridge scenario as well, ensuring that both asynchronous and synchronous steps are merged into a single iFlow.

Please note that the Sync-Async bridge scenario (the opposite from the above), is not supported as of today.

 

Conclusion

In this first blog of the blog series, we explored how to migrate Point-to-Point Asynchronous scenarios and how the Migration Tool simplifies this process by leveraging JMS decoupling and Idempotent Processing. These capabilities help ensure reliable, scalable, and fault-tolerant communication between systems.

entry.title: Java Integration Failures After SAP BTP’s DigiCert G5 Root Certificate Adoption – A Practical Fix
entry.content:
Background

Around seven days ago, SAP replaced its old root certificate, DigiCert Global Root G2, with DigiCert Global Root G5. This change was part of a regular security renewal on SAP’s side — but it caught many Java based applications off guard.

Operating system level trust stores were updated in line with instructions received. But...
While browsers and Windows applications updated their trust automatically, Java runtimes did not.
That’s where things got interesting.

The Symptom

One of our external systems, running on Red Hat OpenJDK — suddenly stopped sending messages to SAP ECC via BTP Integration Suite.

The log showed this familiar (but dreaded) exception:

 
javax.net.ssl.SSLHandshakeException: PKIX path building failed: sun.security.provider.certpath.SunCertPathBuilderException: unable to find valid certification path to requested target

Classic SSL trust failure — and in this case, caused by a missing root certificate.

The Analysis

The new DigiCert Global Root G5 certificate was trusted by Windows but missing in the OpenJDK truststore (cacerts).

Unlike browsers or OS components, this particular JRE maintains its own internal truststore — it doesn’t inherit the operating system’s trusted certificate authorities.

So while everything else trusted the new SAP certificate, the Java runtime didn’t recognize it — and refused to connect.

The Practical Fix

1️⃣ Backup the existing truststore

cd <path_to_redhat_openjdk>\jre\lib\security copy cacerts cacerts.bak

2️⃣ Download the DigiCert Global Root G5 certificate

Get it directly from DigiCert’s official repository:
https://knowledge.digicert.com/generalinformation/digicert-root-and-intermediate-ca-certificates

Save it as g5.cer.

3️⃣ Import the certificate into Java’s truststore

..\..\bin\keytool -importcert -file g5.cer -keystore cacerts -alias "DigiCertG5" 

Default password: changeit
Confirm when prompted.

4️⃣ Verify the import

..\..\bin\keytool -list -keystore cacerts -storepass changeit | find "DigiCertG5"

5️⃣ Restart your application

Restart any Java processes using that truststore.

✅ Result: SSL handshake succeeded.
✅ Message flow from JAVA APP → BTP IS → SAP ECC restored.

 

Lessons Learned

  1. Java ≠ Browser.
    Java doesn’t automatically inherit trusted roots from your OS.

  2. Certificate renewals ripple.
    Cloud platforms like SAP BTP periodically renew CAs — and your Java apps might silently fail afterward.

  3. Test from the runtime, not Chrome.
    Always validate SSL using the same Java runtime your integration runs on.

  4. Keep a “trust refresh” procedure.
    Maintain a documented, repeatable way to update and verify truststores.

  5. Automate where possible. If you manage multiple runtimes, script the import and verification steps.

 

The Bigger Picture

Integration is all about trust — both technically and organizationally.
A single missing certificate can bring down a perfectly built integration chain.

This incident was a reminder: even when nothing changes in your code, something always changes in the environment. And sometimes, that enough to break trust.

entry.title: Migrating SAP PI/PO XI Proxy scenarios to Integration Suite – Key considerations and recommendations
entry.content:
With the recent features in SAP Integration Suite—such as the ability to migrate Service Interfaces from SAP PI/PO to Cloud Integration and the introduction of the pipeline concept, the topic of migrating XI Proxies to Integration Suite has gained fresh significance. If you’ve been waiting for the right moment to move your proxy-based integrations, this might just be it. The following sections outline key considerations and practical recommendations for a smooth and future-ready transition.

A) Modernize While You Migrate

While SAP supports the migration of legacy protocols such as Proxy, helping customers preserve their existing investments, it’s also a good time to consider modernization. Move away from older or proprietary interfaces toward modern, cloud-native, and interoperable options like SOAP or OData services to ensure long-term stability and easier evolution of your integration landscape.

B) Leverage SAP provided Accelerators

Before you start rebuilding interfaces from scratch, explore what SAP already provides out-of-the-box, from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

  • Prepackaged Integration Content: SAP Integration Suite pre-built content can significantly accelerate migration by making use of pre-delivered integration flows, script collections, etc., spanning across key end-to-end business processes, cutting across your SAP and non-SAP systems.
  • Standard APIs and Events: Consume standard APIs and business events available for your SAP S/4HANA edition to avoid / reduce customization and thus keep the core clean.

C) Migrating ESR Proxy Objects to Integration Suite

In the ECC – PI/PO landscape, the Enterprise Services Repository (ESR) served as the central design-time hub for maintaining and versioning proxy schemas and interface definitions. This enabled the well-established “outside-in” development model, where integration developers first defined the structure in middleware via Data type, Message type and Service Interface, after which ABAPers implemented the Proxy class/method in the backend.

When SAP Integration Suite was first introduced, it lacked an ESR-equivalent capability to host and manage proxy schemas. Consequently, one option for customers was to keep their PI/PO ESR systems running to maintain these schemas, regenerate proxies in S/4HANA, and then use Integration Suite iflows for execution.

Additionally, SAP also introduced the Metadata Repository in S/4HANA, allowing schemas to be maintained directly within the backend (via the transaction SPXNMIG)—removing the dependency on ESR. However, this represented a shift from the earlier outside-in model to a more backend-driven (“inside-out”) approach.

With the new feature released in Q3 2025 allowing migration of Service Interface objects from ESR to Integration Suite, it’s now possible to manage proxy schemas directly within Integration Suite—just as you did in PI/PO. This advancement removes the need to depend on S/4HANA’s metadata repository or continue operating ESR purely for schema governance. It reintroduces the familiar outside-in development model, allowing interface definitions to remain in the integration layer.

Please also read this blog post, for additional details on proxy generation based on Service Interface migrated to Integration Suite.

In the following screenshots, we showcase the steps related to migrating an SAP PI/PO service interface to Integration Suite:

Next, to be able to generate proxy at the ABAP backend, we repoint the standard ESR destination "SAP_PROXY_ESR" from PO ESR to Cloud Integration endpoint, as described in this help page.

Once the destination is setup, we proceed to SPROXY transaction. Here we can browse the packages available in Cloud Integration. We navigate through the tree and locate our Service Interface of interest. Then, we generate proxy and complete the ABAP class / method implementation.

This step of migrating your Service Interface object from SAP PI/PO is optional, and you need it only if you want to continue maintaining or modifying the proxy schema in the future. Otherwise, you can proceed directly with migrating runtime artifacts via the migration tooling guided wizard (discussed in the next section below).

D) Migrating Proxy-Based Scenarios (Deployable Components)

While we focused earlier on moving design-time definitions such as Service Interfaces (SI) and Message Types (MT), this step deals with the deployable components that enable actual message processing in Integration Suite.

To clarify the distinction — the Service Interface you migrated in the previous step is not deployed in the Integration Suite tenant. It remains as a repository artifact, referenced by the backend system via SPROXY for proxy generation and linkage at runtime. Its purpose ends there. If, at any point in the future, you need to enhance or extend the schema, you would do so by editing the underlying Message Type that the Service Interface references.

In this step, we focus on migrating the ICO objects as iflows — the deployable components responsible for message execution during runtime.

You can use the migration tooling to convert your existing XI proxy-based configurations into equivalent iflows. Depending on your Migration strategy, you can choose between standard approach or pipeline approach. The pipeline approach offers several operational benefits, such as reduced number of JMS queues, artifact reuse, simplified operations with clearly separated error queues, sophisticated restart mechanisms and Exactly Once message processing – to name a few. Especially for Proxy-based scenarios, the pipeline concept helps in Reliable message processing, decoupling, common entry point for inbound scenarios (as described in the next section). Given these advantages, we recommend that you consider and apply the pipeline concept to migrate your Proxy based scenarios to Integration Suite. Read more about the Pipeline concept in this blog post.

Following screenshot shows the monitoring of an proxy-based end-to-end scenario migrated from SAP PI/PO to Integration Suite, using Migration tooling (Pipeline approach). We have not discussed the detailed steps related to Pipeline concept, as it is already dealt with in multiple posts.

E) Establishing a Common Entry Point

Establish a common entry point for all inbound XI Proxy messages either by modelling your own generic inbound iflow for XI, or leveraging the out-of-the-box generic XI inbound iflow that comes as part of the pipeline concept. The common entry point mirrors the Generic XI Sender Channel setup you may recall from SAP PI/PO. The generic XI inbound iflow, shipped as part of the generic pipeline package is impressively versatile—it can handle all QoS (Exactly Once, Exactly Once in Order, and Best Effort) without additional development or configuration effort. That’s yet another strong reason to choose the pipeline approach.

F) Configuring a Single Destination

As a corollary of setting up a common entry-point iflow, only one HTTP destination is required from your SAP S/4HANA system—pointing to this generic inbound iflow. This simplifies connectivity setup and minimizes administrative overhead.

G) Sender/Receiver-Specific Queues and Federated Landscape Design in Pipeline-Based Proxy Migrations

In this section, we’ll discuss two aspects that could come into play at the intersection of XI Proxy migration and the pipeline concept in SAP Integration Suite:

1) Defining Sender/Receiver-Specific Queues
In classic SAP PI/PO, message monitoring could be conveniently filtered by Communication Component, giving operations team a clear view of message traffic per backend system. While Integration Suite does not mirror this behaviour directly, a similar outcome can be achieved within the pipeline setup by defining sender- or receiver-specific JMS queues. This approach allows message segregation per system, targeted retries, and operational isolation without interfering with other integrations. More details on configuring sender / receiver specific JMS queues for pipeline can be found in this Help portal page.

2) setting up separate pipelines for federated landscapes
Many enterprises historically operated multiple ABAP backends—such as Finance, SRM, or CRM—supported by distinct PI/PO systems aligned by Line of Business (LoB) or regional boundaries. As these organizations move toward Integration Suite modernization and consolidate middleware into a single tenant, it remains important to retain autonomy and governance separation across business domains.

The pipeline approach enables this by allowing you to replicate the standard pipeline package into individual design workspaces—one per LoB or region—supported by consistent artifact naming conventions and Access Policies that control visibility and ownership. This setup helps balance consolidation with distributed control, ensuring each domain can manage its proxy-based integration flows independently.
With this rationale in mind, SAP has published the New Integration Packages for the Pipeline for Cloud Integration.

Following screenshots illustrate creation and consumption of an additional instance of a generic Pipeline package, so that we can run the separate pipeline to be used by integrations related to a specific backend (in this case, called RI4).

This model preserves the federated operating style of large enterprises while streamlining governance, monitoring, and operations within a single, cloud-native Integration Suite tenant.

While the considerations in this section—queue separation and federated pipelines—are applicable to other interface types and protocols as well, they are highlighted here because proxy-based interfaces typically form a significant portion of many organizations’ legacy landscape. Addressing these design aspects as part of proxy migration ensures that modernization efforts not only move interfaces to the cloud but also align with scalable, operationally sustainable integration practices suited for the long term.

Most PI/PO systems carry a large footprint of Proxy interfaces. Migrating them to Integration Suite is not just about tool-based conversion but about adopting patterns that keep the setup clean and maintainable in the long run. With the right approach in place, the transition becomes less of a migration task and more of a steady move toward a simplified, future-ready integration landscape.

entry.title: Complete Guide: Setting Up CAP Plugin for Advanced Event Mesh with OAuth Authentication
entry.content:
Introduction

This blog is the result of the steps taken to successfully use the official CAP plugin for Advanced Event Mesh. It took some time to set it up through a series of trial-and-error approaches. I knew I couldn't keep everything in mind, so initially this content was intended to be the README.md file of the resulting repository.

There is plenty of material in the Community that speaks about the setup steps of the prerequisites, including a dedicated chapter in the official SAP Help:

  • Securing SAP Advanced Event Mesh: OAuth Configuration and SEMP API Integration by Carlos Roggan
  • Securing Advanced Event Mesh: Comprehensive Guide to OAuth Configuration in Broker Manager by Carlos Roggan
  • SAP Cloud Integration: Advanced Event Mesh Adapter series, also by Carlos Roggan
  • Setup CAP Plugin from the official documentation

This blog ties all these pieces together into a single end-to-end guide.

Prerequisites

Before starting, ensure you have:

  • An active subscription of Advanced Event Mesh (AEM), or a subaccount in which you have AEM entitlement
  • Administrative access to Identity Authentication Services (IAS)
  • Cloud Foundry CLI installed and configured
  • A REST client (Postman, Hoppscotch, Bruno, or cURL)
  • CAP development environment set up

Scope of This Guide

Important: This guide covers Authentication only, not Authorization, and specifically for the CAP Plugin. All other use cases are already covered in the referenced blogs by Carlos Roggan.

Values Reference Guide

Throughout this guide, we'll collect several values that will be reused multiple times. Values highlighted in green are critical configuration values you'll need to reference later. Keep them in a secure note-taking application as you progress through the steps.

 

SAP Identity Authentication Services

The CAP plugin requires OAuth-based access to work. We need an Identity Provider capable of generating JWT tokens for connecting to the AEM Service. For this, we'll use Identity Authentication Services (IAS).

Create an OIDC Application

Navigate to the IAS Administration console, then select the Application & Resources menu entry:

  • Select Create from the header of the left-side navigation list
  • Fill in the following attributes:
    • Application Name: Choose a descriptive name
    • Type: Set to SAP BTP Solution
    • Protocol Type: Set to OpenID Connect
  • Select Create

The Application Details page opens. Complete these two configuration steps:

Configure OpenID Connect

  • Select the OpenID Connect Configuration list entry
    • Enter a configuration name (can be any descriptive name), then select Save
    • Scroll down to the Grant Types section
    • Ensure that Client Credentials, JWT Bearer, and Refresh Token are toggled On
    • You may enable other options, but they are not required for this guide

Create Client Credentials

  • Scroll down to Client Authentication and select this list entry
  • Navigate to the Secrets section and select Add
  • This creates a dedicated Client ID and corresponding Client Secret for JWT token generation:
    • Enter a meaningful name for the secret
    • Select the OIDC Scopes: at minimum, choose OpenID
    • Select Save

⚠️CRITICAL: Copy the Client ID and Client Secret from the pop-up immediately. The secret cannot be retrieved later—if lost, you'll need to generate a new one.

Collect IAS Configuration Values

Before proceeding to AEM configuration, collect these values. Fields in green are required for creating the OAuth Profile in the Broker Manager:

  • Client ID (from the previous step)
  • Client Secret (from the previous step)
  • OIDC Issuer Information:
    • Navigate to Application & Resources → Tenant Settings → Single Sign-On → OpenID Connect Configuration
    • Copy the URL value from the Issuer section: this is your Issuer Identifier
    • Select the Show Discovery Endpoint button
    • Copy the URL from the browser window that opens: this is your Discovery Endpoint

Test Token Generation

Let's verify that the client credentials can successfully generate JWT tokens.

Using your preferred REST client (Postman, Hoppscotch, Bruno, or cURL), execute the following request:

curl -X POST "https://youriastenant/oauth2/token" \
-H "Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded" \
-d "grant_type=client_credentials" \
-d "client_id=" \
-d "client_secret=" \
-d "token_format=jwt"

A successful request returns HTTP 200 with a response similar to:

{
  "access_token": "eyJqa3UiOiJodHRwczovL2FtY21nYmpwZS5hY2NvdW50cy5jbG91ZC5zYXAvb2F1dGgyL2NlcnRzIiwia2lkIjoiTjdvNU1aSW5jR1ltelIzcmtNaVlTYkZWcW1zIiwiYWxnIjoiUlMyNTYifQ..NvjwTzyfua785jqLWGWkDP7quLhFMzVhundvMjitkOWVr3snb7pL0Z3nHNvHy0qYo6DadIpSHUVA3pchAR0xvhlXKgIRhX4hMRp2T1JzNTm9sVV7Mv92Bxt3Q990-vQh3DhHZj_pkqvDMflo8hpcobgXwQyy0sXGPI7GM_BChQ74BoqiR9m28jvVKxwtJh18d_Gc4d1J3hJzUxs2m4Gec-Lose7B63WkfwXeeprMW_RLdOCKvOGfuWbMQBPJWjJnfr4ayE3Uq2wEtFZEylFvQjMDsd1otO-_ZRmZwbs76DHf5TD2CBH0Up9LwKH8Ww87gcn9T8ULSbiV4ijQenaa2g",
  "token_type": "Bearer",
  "expires_in": 3600
}

Verify Token Contents

Copy the value of the access_token property and navigate to jwt.io. Paste the token value in the left-hand textarea (Encoded section), replacing the default values. You should see the decoded token on the right:

{
  "sub": "b52ed1e3-125c-4eb5-ba95-48de30102850",
  "aud": "b52ed1e3-125c-4eb5-ba95-48de30102850",
  "azp": "b52ed1e3-125c-4eb5-ba95-48de30102850",
  "iss": "https://amcmgbjpe.accounts.cloud.sap",
  "azpacr": "1",
  "exp": 1762800894,
  "iat": 1762797294,
  "jti": "5bfccdab-9902-483b-83e6-50ddd820353f"
}

Note that the sub value matches your Client ID and the iss value is your Identity Authentication tenant (the token issuer).

With IAS successfully configured to generate JWT tokens, we're ready to configure AEM to accept these tokens for authentication.

 

SAP Advanced Event Mesh

(Optional) Create a Service Broker

Skip this step if you already have a Service Broker you'd like to use.

Open the AEM Cluster Manager and select the Create Service button on the Services page. You'll be prompted to provide the following details:

  • Service Name: Choose a descriptive name
  • Cloud Provider: Select your preferred provider (e.g., AWS)
  • Region: Choose the region nearest to you (e.g., eu-south-1)
  • Version: Keep the default or specify a version
  • Service Type: For this tutorial, Developer (Broker-100) is sufficient
  • Advanced Connection Options:
    • Expand this section and review the Message VPN Name
    • It's auto-generated from your Service Name, but you can customize it
    • Choose something memorable—you'll need this value frequently

Select Create Service at the bottom right to continue.

Service Broker Details

Create the OAuth Profile for the Broker Manager

Navigate to the Cluster Manager and open your Service Broker.

In the top navigation menu, select Manage, then select the Access Control link in the left-hand navigation menu under Broker Manager Quick Links.

Service Management

The Access Control page opens to the Client Authentication → Settings sub-section.

Select OAuth Profile (located after the Settings sub-section). Here we'll create a new OAuth Profile and set it as the default.

OAuth Profile

Select "+ OAuth Profile" in the top-right corner and provide a profile name (e.g., IAS_BASED_ACCESS).

Configure OAuth Profile Attributes

In the configuration screen, fill in the following attributes using the green-highlighted values we collected from IAS:

AttributeValueNotes
EnabledtrueEnable the profile
OAuth Client IDClient IDFrom IAS Application
OAuth Client Secret
(click Change OAuth Client Secret)		Client SecretFrom IAS Application
OAuth RoleResource ServerAEM acts as resource server
Disconnect on Token ExpirationtrueRecommended for security
Issuer IdentifierIssuer IdentifierFrom IAS Tenant Settings
Discovery EndpointDiscovery EndpointFrom IAS Tenant Settings
Parse Access TokentrueRequired for validation
Validate Access Token AudiencetrueValidates token audience
Required AudienceClient IDFrom IAS Application
Validate Access Token IssuertrueValidates token issuer
Required IssuerIssuer IdentifierFrom IAS Tenant Settings
Validate Access Token ScopefalseNot required for this setup
Validate Access Token TypefalseNot required for this setup

Save the profile.

Create a Client Username

This step is essential for AEM to recognize your Client ID as a valid username. It's simple but easy to forget.

Navigate back to the Access Control page, then select Client Usernames in the main navigation menu:

Client Usernames

Select "+ Client Username" and in the pop-up that appears, enter your Client ID. In the configuration page that opens, set:

AttributeValueNotes
EnabledtrueEnable the client
Client ProfiledefaultUse default profile
ACL ProfiledefaultUse default ACL
Guaranteed Endpoint Permission Override(leave default)No override needed
Subscription ManagertrueAllow subscription management

Save the Client Username.

Set the Default OAuth Profile

Navigate to Client Authentication → Settings, scroll down to the OAuth Authentication setting, and toggle it On. From the drop-down menu, select the profile we just created (e.g., IAS_BASED_ACCESS) as the Default Profile Name:

OAuth Authentication default profile

We're done with the UI-based configuration in AEM! Next, we'll configure the SEMP API.

Add the OAuth Profile to the SEMP API

The CAP plugin uses the SEMP (Solace Element Management Protocol) API to manage broker elements. It requires an OAuth Configuration on the SEMP side as well.

We can reuse the values configured in the Broker Manager, but we must perform these changes using the Solace SEMP REST API (no UI is available).

The SEMP API endpoints are visible from Cluster Manager → Service Details under the Connect section. Scroll down to Connect with Management Tools:

SEMP

To create the OAuth Profile initially, we need:

  • A personal access token for authentication
  • Your Service technical ID
  • The Solace Cloud API endpoint

Create a Personal Access Token

From the Cluster Manager page, select the User icon at the bottom left, then select Token Management.

Select Create Token in the top-right corner. Provide a token name and select the required scopes. For experimentation, you can select all scopes. For more information, see the Solace API documentation.

Select Create Token at the bottom right and copy the generated token immediately—you won't be able to view it again.

Get the Service Technical ID

Navigate to Cluster Manager → Service Details for your service and scroll down to the Availability and Versioning section. Copy the Service ID.

Call the Solace Cloud API

Using your preferred REST client, execute the following request. Replace the placeholders in the JSON payload:

AttributeValue
clientIdClient ID
clientSecretClient Secret
endpointDiscoveryDiscovery Endpoint
oauthProfileNameChoose a unique profile name (e.g., "clientcredentials_ias")
resourceServerRequiredIssuerIssuer Identifier
resourceServerRequiredAudienceClient ID

Replace <your_service_id> with your Service technical ID and <your_PAT_Token> with your Personal Access Token:

curl --request POST \
--url https://api.solace.cloud/api/v2/missionControl/eventBrokerServices/your_service_id/broker/SEMP/v2/config/oauthProfiles \
--header 'Authorization: Bearer your_pat_token' \
--header 'content-type: application/json' \
--data '{
  "clientId": "Client ID",
  "clientSecret": "Client Secret",
  "defaultGlobalAccessLevel": "read-only",
  "defaultMsgVpnAccessLevel": "read-write",
  "enabled": true,
  "endpointDiscovery": "Discovery Endpoint",
  "issuer": "Issuer",
  "oauthProfileName": "clientcredentials_ias",
  "oauthRole": "resource-server",
  "resourceServerParseAccessTokenEnabled": false,
  "resourceServerValidateIssuerEnabled": true,
  "resourceServerRequiredIssuer": "Issuer",
  "resourceServerValidateAudienceEnabled": true,
  "resourceServerRequiredAudience": "Client ID",
  "resourceServerValidateTypeEnabled": true,
  "resourceServerRequiredType": "JWT",
  "resourceServerValidateScopeEnabled": false,
  "sempEnabled": true
}'

A successful request returns HTTP 200 with the complete OAuth Profile definition.

⚠️Troubleshooting: If you receive an error like "Your permissions have changed," verify your Personal Access Token is correct.

Modifying the Profile

Inspect the returned JSON and verify all values. If corrections are needed, you must delete and recreate the profile (PUT/PATCH operations are not supported):

curl --request DELETE \
  --url https://api.solace.cloud/api/v2/missionControl/eventBrokerServices/your_service_id/broker/SEMP/v2/config/oauthProfiles/ \
  --header 'Authorization: Bearer your_pat_token'

Then execute the POST request again with corrected values. Repeat as needed until the configuration is correct.

Test the SEMP Configuration

Let's verify the new OAuth Configuration in SEMP works correctly.

We'll obtain an access token from IAS and use it to invoke the SEMP API. This time, we'll use your cluster's SEMP API endpoint (not the global Solace Cloud API).

Replace the placeholder values in the commands below:

# Get IAS Token:
curl --request POST \
  --url https://your_ias_tenant/oauth2/token \
  --header 'content-type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded' \
  --data grant_type=client_credentials \
  --data client_id=your_client_id\
  --data response_type=token \
  --data client_secret=your_client_secret

# Call the SEMP API with the generated token:
curl --request GET \
  --url https://your_semp_endpoint:943/SEMP/v2/config/msgVpns//queues \
  --header 'Authorization: Bearer ias_generated_token'

Regardless of the JSON response content, the last call should return HTTP 200. If you receive a 401 Unauthorized error, review your OAuth Profile creation and try deleting and recreating it.

 

Integrate with CAP

We've reached the final step—creating a CAP application that connects to our Broker using OAuth authentication.

Prerequisites

Following the official documentation, we need:

  • An instance of service aem-validation-service with plan aem-validation-service-plan
  • A user-provided service (UPS) instance containing the IAS and Broker endpoint configuration

Create the AEM Validation Service

Create the service instance and service key:

cf create-service aem-validation-service aem-validation-service-plan 
cf create-service-key

Create the User-Provided Service

Important: The service must be named exactly advanced-event-mesh.

cf create-user-provided-service advanced-event-mesh -p '{
  "authentication-service": {
    "clientid": "your_IAS_Client_ID",
    "clientsecret": "your_IAS_Client_Secret",
    "tokenendpoint": "https://your_IAS_Tenant/oauth2/token"
  },
  "endpoints": {
    "advanced-event-mesh": {
      "smf_uri": "wss://yourserviceendpoint:443",
      "uri": "https://yourserviceendpoint:9443"
    }
  },
  "vpn": "your_service_vpn_name"
}'

Replace all placeholder values with your actual configuration.

Find Endpoint Values

To find values for endpoints.advanced-event-mesh:

  1. Navigate to Cluster Manager → Service Details → Connect
  2. Open the Node.js connection section

Node.Js connection params

  • Select web-messaging to get the smf_uri value
  • Select rest to get the uri value

For the vpn value, navigate to Cluster Manager → Service Details, locate the DMR Cluster section, and copy the Message VPN property.

Create the CAP Application

Initialize a new CAP application:

cds init my-aem-powered-app
cd my-aem-powered-app
npm add -js/advanced-event-mesh
npm install
cds bind aem-validation-service -2 aem-validation-service:yourkeyname --for hybrid --kind aem-validation-service
cds bind advanced-event-mesh -2 advanced-event-mesh --for hybrid --kind user-provided

Add a Service Definition

Create a service definition of your choice. This example uses a simple purchase order service:

service AdminService {
    entity PurchaseOrderHeaders as projection on db.PurchaseOrderHeader {
        *,
        items: redirected to PurchaseOrderItems,
        supplier: redirected to Suppliers,
    }
    entity PurchaseOrderItems   as projection on db.PurchaseOrderItem {
        *,
        PurchaseOrderHeader: redirected to PurchaseOrderHeaders
    };
    
    entity Suppliers            as projection on db.Supplier;
}

Configure the Advanced Event Mesh Plugin

Update your .cdsrc.json file to configure the messaging plugin:

{
    "requires": {
        "messaging": {
            "kind": "advanced-event-mesh"
        }
    }
}

Add Event Publishing Logic

Implement logic to publish events when entities are created or updated:

import cds from "@sap/cds";
const LOG = cds.log("admin-service");

export default class AdminService extends cds.ApplicationService {
    async init() {
        await super.init();

        const messaging = await cds.connect.to("messaging");
        
        this.after(["CREATE", "UPDATE"], "PurchaseOrderHeaders", async (data, req) => {
            LOG.info(`Purchase Order ${req.event === 'CREATE' ? 'Created' : 'Updated'} with ID: ${data.ID} and Name: ${data.Name}`);
            
            // Emit the event
            try {
                await messaging.emit(
                    req.event === 'CREATE' ? 
                        "cap/msg/admin/purchaseorder/created" : 
                        "cap/msg/admin/purchaseorder/updated",
                    {
                        ID: data.ID,
                        Name: data.Name,
                    },
                    { 
                        headers: { 
                            "X-Correlation-ID": req.headers["x-correlation-id"] 
                        } 
                    }
                );
            } catch (error) {
                LOG.error(`Error emitting event: ${error.message}`);
                return req.reject(500, `Failed to emit event: ${error.message}`);
            }
        });
    }
}

Run the Application

For initial testing, run the application with the messaging debug flag:

DEBUG=messaging cds watch --profile hybrid

Inspect the terminal output. If everything is configured correctly, you'll see connection logs similar to (abbreviated for brevity):

# ... initialization logs ...
[advanced-event-mesh] - solclientjs: websocket browserSupportBinaryCheck: true - WebSocket supports binaryType
[advanced-event-mesh] - solclientjs: [session-fsm=N/A] [WaitingForDNS] Creating transport session wss://yourserviceendpoint:443/
[advanced-event-mesh] - solclientjs: websocket browserSupportBinaryCheck: true - WebSocket supports binaryType
[advanced-event-mesh] - solclientjs: Connect Transport WS_BINARY
[advanced-event-mesh] - solclientjs: Establishing WebSocket transport session
[advanced-event-mesh] - solclientjs: Constructing socket
[advanced-event-mesh] - solclientjs: WebSocket is connecting
# ... [abbreviated for brevity] ...
[advanced-event-mesh] - solclientjs: Web transport receive transport event: {
  transportEventCode: 'UP_NOTICE (1)',
  infoStr: 'Connected',
  responseCode: 0,
  errorSubcode: '',
  sid: 'N/A'
}
# ... connection established logs ...
[cds] - connect to messaging > advanced-event-mesh {authentication-service: {...}, endpoints: {...}, vpn: 'yourservicename'}
# ... ready to serve requests ...

End-to-End Test

Before testing the complete flow, set up a subscriber in AEM to receive the published messages.

Connect as a Subscriber

  1. Navigate to Cluster Manager → Service Details → Try Me! section
  2. Note the Client Username and Password displayed
  3. Select Open Broker Manager

Try Me! Page

Configure the Subscriber

In the right-hand Subscriber section:

  1. Connect to the Broker (you may need to uncheck the Same as Publisher option)
  2. Once connected, scroll down to the Subscribe section
  3. Enter the topic you're publishing from CAP:
    • cap/msg/admin/purchaseorder/created
    • cap/msg/admin/purchaseorder/updated
  4. Select Subscribe

Trigger an Event

Return to your CAP application and create or update a Purchase Order entity. In the AEM Try Me! section, you should see your message appear:

Receiving message on topic

 

Troubleshooting Common Issues

401 Unauthorized on SEMP API

Symptom: SEMP API calls return 401 Unauthorized.

Solution: Verify the OAuth Profile configuration in SEMP. Delete and recreate the profile if necessary, ensuring all values match your IAS configuration.

Token Generation Fails

Symptom: Cannot generate JWT tokens from IAS.

Solution: Verify the Client ID and Client Secret are correct. Ensure the Grant Types (Client Credentials, JWT Bearer) are enabled in the OIDC configuration.

CAP Application Cannot Connect

Symptom: CAP application fails to establish WebSocket connection.

Solution: Verify the user-provided service configuration. Ensure the smf_uri and uri endpoints are correct and the VPN name matches your service. Double check if the OAuth Profile is active and set as default in the Broker Manager.

Conclusion

We covered:

  • Configuring IAS as an OAuth provider
  • Setting up OAuth profiles in AEM Broker Manager and SEMP API
  • Creating and testing a CAP application with event publishing
  • Verifying end-to-end message flow

Thank you for following this long article!

The referenced materials provide additional context and details for specific use cases. Kudos go to the respective authors.

For questions or additional support, please refer to the official SAP documentation or reach out via the SAP Community.

All the best,

Roberto.

entry.title: Join SAP Usability Testing Sessions at SAP TechEd Bangalore - Influence your Product Experience
entry.content:
Join our live usability testing session at SAP TechEd Bangalore on November 25-26, 2025.

Usability testing offers a unique opportunity for SAP users to engage directly with the SAP product and development teams. In a focused 60-minute one-on-one session, you’ll interact with product screens and evaluate whether the buttons, terminology, and features meet your expectations and workflow needs

If you've ever thought, "Why can’t I just click here and make it work?" — this is your chance to influence exactly that. Your feedback helps us create intuitive, user-friendly solutions that better support your business.

Prerequisites for participating in usability testing at SAP TechEd Bangalore

  1. To be able to participate, you need to be an attendee at SAP TechEd Bangalore.
  2. You need to have experience with using the product for which you’d like to participate in a Usability Test.

What you need to know about the registration process

  1. We use the Bookings app to manage registrations for Usability Tests at SAP TechEd. Your data will be stored in our forms on the booking platform. To the extent that the entered information is personal data, SAP will use it in accordance with this privacy statement.
  2. Use the links below to register for the Usability Test Stations at SAP TechEd Bangalore and pick one of the available time slots for the test session.
    Please arrive at the Usability Test Lab 10 minutes before your scheduled time.
  3. Please sign up with your business email address – it will only be used for scheduling your test session; you will not receive marketing because of this registration.
  4. Email notifications will be sent from Usability Testing Lab Participant Interest Form <UsabilityTestingLabRegistration@sap.onmicrosoft.com>  Please check your SPAM/JUNK folder in case you do not receive the confirmation emails.
  5. Interested in future online user research opportunities after SAP TechEd?
    To receive invitations, please complete the registration form for the SAP User Research Panel.
    If you don’t sign up, your contact information will be deleted four weeks after the event in accordance with our data privacy policy.

Usability Test Stations

Usability Test Station 1: 
Integration Flow generation using AI & Groovy scripts readiness for Integration Cell runtime


Test the AI feature for creating integration flows from scenario descriptions (including Groovy script steps) with error handling. Evaluate Groovy script readiness for the upcoming Integration Cell runtime and explore integration flow creation via Joule using high-fidelity prototypes.

Test Conditional Task Chains and Port Connections in SAP Datasphere, BDC

This session focuses on evaluating the new ability to react to task outcomes and define conditional execution paths using dedicated ports:

  • Any (blue)

These enhancements aim to give users greater control and flexibility in orchestrating complex workflows. Alongside these, participants will also explore other new capabilities introduced to improve error handling and configurability.

A key focus of this session is to assess both usability and the durability of interactions — ensuring that the experience remains stable, intuitive, and efficient across varied use cases.

Your feedback will help us refine and improve our workflows even further.

Participants need to have experience with cloud implementations and end-user knowledge to participate.

The focus is on exploring how Joule can support users through end-to-end process creation by providing intelligent suggestions, automating repetitive steps, and enabling seamless collaboration with key stakeholders. We aim to understand usability, clarity of guidance, efficiency gains, and how well Joule integrates into existing SAP Build Process Automation workflows. Participant feedback will help refine the interaction model and identify opportunities for enhancing agentic assistance in real scenarios.

SAP Fiori tools are designed to lower the entry barrier for new teams while providing the advanced capabilities and flexibility that experienced developers demand. In this usability session, you can experiment with some of our early AI-driven features, provide feedback on our tools and our vision, and directly influence our direction for the next generation of intelligent development tools.

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite - Process Pallete Function
entry.content:
Process Palette Function

Process Pallete Function has three types:

  1. Integration Process
  2. Exception Sub Process
  3. Local Integration Process

 

Integration Process:

  • Act as a main workflow container for iFlows.
  • In integration process we can can perform the custom iFlow job.
  • Enables orchestration of different steps like content modification, transformation, and routing.

 

Exception Sub Process:

  • Handles errors in the Integration Process.
  • Starts with an Error Start Event.
  • Useful for logging, alerts, or fallback steps.

If any error occurs in integration process we can perform exception sub process (error handling). Exception Subprocess starts with Error Start Event. 

 

Local Integration Process:

  • A reusable mini process within the iFlow.
  • Called using Process Call.
  • Helps avoid repeating the same logic in multiple places.

We can perform whole integration process by single process call function by using Local Integration Process.
